pullrequest.title: Handle authentication error connecting to lyse

content.raw:
I can’t reproduce the incorrect auth setup you had in mind for this. I tried running lyse on a remote host with:

1. A local zlock server and no encryption: 

    * lyse starts but blacs does connect to the analysis host.
    * The tooltip reads ‘Server not responding. No response from server: timed out’.
    * ![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/dR5qxr/images/509204352-blacs_analysis.png)
    
2. A common zlock sever that has encryption enabled, but with`allow_insecure = True`:

    * lyse starts and gets sent shots to analyse by blacs.
    
3. A common zlock server that has encryption enabled, but with an invalid shared secret on the remote host:

    * lyse fails to start with `zprocess.security.AuthenticationFailure`as you would expect. Specifically, the zmq message that elicits this is `zmq.EVENT_HANDSHAKE_NO_DETAIL`, as determined by uncommenting [this print statement](https://bitbucket.org/cbillington/zprocess/src/139dcc6a98451b335eae46554efc13b28cdbd59e/zprocess/security.py?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#security.py-222) in security.py of zprocess.
content.html:
I can’t reproduce the incorrect auth setup you had in mind for this. I tried running lyse on a remote host with:

  1. A local zlock server and no encryption:

    • lyse starts but blacs does connect to the analysis host.
    • The tooltip reads ‘Server not responding. No response from server: timed out’.

  2. A common zlock sever that has encryption enabled, but withallow_insecure = True:

    • lyse starts and gets sent shots to analyse by blacs.

  3. A common zlock server that has encryption enabled, but with an invalid shared secret on the remote host:

    • lyse fails to start with zprocess.security.AuthenticationFailureas you would expect. Specifically, the zmq message that elicits this is zmq.EVENT_HANDSHAKE_NO_DETAIL, as determined by uncommenting this print statement in security.py of zprocess.
